name: NPR
text:
Many law enforcement agencies in suburban Minneapolis and St. Paul that policed protests were the beneficiaries of a Pentagon program that distributed more than $1 billion worth of military gear to local police departments. 
https://t.co/UNe9zO3ceN

name: NPR
text:
In an April survey of nearly 500 Wisconsinites with disabilities and older adults, every respondent said COVID-19 has disrupted their caregiving service.

And the state was already facing a shortage of caregivers before the pandemic.
https://t.co/xsoaQL8pLa

name: NPR
text:
Lainy is a preschool teacher who's been out of work since mid-March.

Because preschool teachers are "chronically underpaid," she says, unemployment benefits add up to about $500 a month more than she made when she was working.
https://t.co/6zAUEgVK4q

name: NPR
text:
Black women experience higher rates of diseases and suffer from stressors of systemic racism.

GirlTrek is organizing team walks to foster health and healing.

"When women walked and talked together," says co-founder T. Morgan Dixon, "everything changed."
https://t.co/FGkhxPTmJs

name: NPR
text:
A few tips for making the workplace more equitable for your trans coworkers:

• Do your own research instead of asking intrusive questions

• Be intentional about your language and correct mistakes

• Look beyond inclusion and push for true equity
https://t.co/TeT9uGVPrd

name: NPR
text:
The Justice Department is suing former national security adviser John Bolton to block the publication of his tell-all memoir. The lawsuit alleges the book would compromise national security.
https://t.co/mq7qUmMU8s

name: NPR
text: RT @rdlewis: Florida, Texas and Arizona all moved to reopen quickly and now have set daily records for the number of COVID-19 cases. In Florida, officials are sparring over exactly why the numbers are going up so quickly (by @gallennpr) https://t.co/N6b7rOP8FM

name: NPR
text: The University of Virginia will change the athletic department's logo because it contains a reference to the university's history with slavery. https://t.co/blQwy8lQBa

name: NPR
text:
The Navy is mobilizing 1,629 reservists to help reduce the aircraft and submarine maintenance backlog that has developed because of the COVID-19 pandemic. 
https://t.co/QxZi8xiQcY

name: NPR
text:
No Federal Reserve chair has ever been publicly ridiculed as much as Jerome Powell. And that's despite the central bank's unprecedented efforts to save the American economy.

But Powell shows no sign of caving to pressure.
https://t.co/XmnCYqpw9B

name: NPR
text:
Thailand's coronavirus lockdown has kept the number of cases low. But the economic toll has led to a mental health crisis.
https://t.co/fvBCjbHAAk

name: NPR
text: If you or someone you know may be considering suicide, call the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-… https://t.co/agIxc1ZwbF

name: NPR
text:
Gov. Greg Abbott has barred Texas cities from implementing any rules that would require face coverings — despite a concerning uptick in the number of COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations in the state. 
https://t.co/oycrTAgK7P

name: NPR
text:
Across the country, libraries have seen demand skyrocket for e-books.

By one estimate, weekly library e-book lending in the U.S. has increased almost 50% since March 9.
https://t.co/ohaC4IuDlP

name: NPR
text:
The U.S. Open Tennis Tournament will take place as scheduled this summer — without fans in the stand due to the pandemic.

Australian tennis star Nicholas Kyrgios called the move "selfish."
https://t.co/AIMJkaZveJ

name: NPR
text:
Florida saw 2,783 new COVID-19 cases Tuesday — the third time in a week the state set a new daily record.

While Gov. Ron DeSantis says the increase was expected, local officials are concerned about other statistics that show the virus is still spreading. https://t.co/pnnc5eE0pn

name: NPR
text:
PG&E has pleaded guilty to 84 separate counts of involuntary manslaughter and one felony count of unlawfully starting a fire in a case stemming from the devastating 2018 Camp Fire. The settlement amounts to $25.5 billion.
https://t.co/PWwSN5SSbR

name: NPR
text:
NFL commissioner Roger Goodell is encouraging teams to sign former quarterback Colin Kaepernick, who hasn’t played in the league since 2016.
https://t.co/3Gchbx4rsZ

name: NPR
text: Even though some restaurants are opening up for patio service, public health officials say that doesn’t mean there's no risk of COVID-19. @WBEZCuriousCity asked experts for their safety tips, including how to choose where and with whom to eat. https://t.co/FpMikGICTD

name: NPR
text:
A third of the city budget in Columbus, Ohio, goes to law enforcement. 

Police department line items can outpace other high-priority funding. The city spends more on police vehicle fuel and maintenance than it does on affordable housing. @WOSU https://t.co/nnieymLdX1

name: NPR
text: Auður Ava Ólafsdóttir's atmospheric novel, “Miss Iceland,” will transport you to another time and place — though not necessarily a rosier time and place. https://t.co/StbfX5Zeix

name: NPR
text:
From virtual school to missing Grandma, children all over the country sent us impressive postcards about their lives. 

Here’s a glimpse of what it’s like to be a kid right now. 👇https://t.co/pRMGoBugtZ

name: NPR
text:
Music is canonizing this moment in history at rapid speed. 

Whether it's a trap anthem for the protests or a tale of petty deceit, this week's Heat Check considers the bigger picture. 👇
https://t.co/3blo7np2CE

name: NPR
text:
Mt. Joy was recently on the road with The Lumineers when the tour was cut short by the pandemic. 

But even during quarantine — it's hard to keep these road warriors from making music. 👇
https://t.co/Pvqd4Vnmjq

name: NPR
text: "Racism has been our Achilles' heel for a long time, and it's been the cancer that has just been killing us," author James McBride tells @samsanders on @NPRItsBeenAMin. "And now we want to address the problem." https://t.co/iKvHDcdetA

name: NPR
text:
2020 has already been a lot. 

Cellist Yo-Yo Ma has been coping — and trying to help the rest of us cope — with videos of himself playing what he calls "Songs of Comfort."
 https://t.co/0IuV8Yh5fo

name: NPR
text: The pandemic prompted authorities around the U.S. to protect renters from eviction. But not everyone is covered, and some landlords are turning to threats and harassment to force tenants out. @wamu885 https://t.co/SpJAEfycFw

name: NPR
text:
Gov. Andrew Cuomo: "What the community is now saying, all across this nation, 'We don't want this type of police force.' And if they don't want it, they shouldn't have it."
https://t.co/VKZsOaiqev

name: NPR
text:
Thailand's Ministry of Public Health says now that the threat of COVID-19 is under control, "the next wave of the problem will be mental health."
https://t.co/gIueXh5QIj

name: NPR
text:
President Trump has slipped in many of the key swing states he won in 2016—like Michigan, which currently appears to lean toward Joe Biden, an NPR analysis finds.

But November is still 5 months away, and Biden is short of solidifying 270 electoral votes.
https://t.co/gKqGqzNN1u

name: NPR
text:
A South Dakota biotech company is using cows — with genes from the human immune system — to create antibodies, with the aim of treating or even preventing COVID-19.
https://t.co/OcRbZKlaKq

name: NPR
text:
Lower-income people are now spending almost as much as they did before the pandemic, researchers say. But the wealthiest households in the U.S. are not — which could limit the whole country's economic recovery.
https://t.co/VprVnxryO9

name: NPR
text:
Quaker Foods has announced it's changing the name and logo of "Aunt Jemima" — acknowledging the brand's origins rooted in a racist stereotype.
https://t.co/KHSGIPaYWn

name: NPR
text: The police chief in Richmond, Va., has resigned after Mayor Levar Stoney asked him to do so. Videos showed officers… https://t.co/480Q8Qybcr

name: NPR
text:
Brazil reported a record of nearly 35,000 new coronavirus cases in a 24-hour period — even as the government has insisted the outbreak is under control.

State health departments say that figure is probably undercounted by a few thousand.
https://t.co/VXbz4q36MI

name: NPR
text:
By one estimate, at least 217 Republican women have filed to run for the House in 2020. That's already close to doubling the previous record of 133 a decade ago.
https://t.co/Dnnh05sSYh

name: NPR
text:
Food giant Mars now says it's "evaluating all possibilities" for changing its Uncle Ben's brand — which has long been criticized as a stereotype. 

The move comes after news that Aunt Jemima will be changing its name and image.
https://t.co/as3KLjrAq7

name: NPR
text: A new report says a disinformation campaign, dubbed "Secondary Infektion," has sought to spread Russian propaganda… https://t.co/23FCAmBO6R

name: NPR
text:
Police didn't use lethal force on the white supremacist who murdered 9 worshippers at a black church in 2015. In jail, he got Burger King.

"There was tremendous difference in his arrest and what we've seen the last several days," said Rep. James Clyburn. https://t.co/TZU7a1nyXZ

name: NPR
text:
USAID, the primary humanitarian aid agency, has always been separate from the overtly political State Department.

But the White House and Senate are proposing changes to that.
https://t.co/vcOPRkbqos

name: NPR
text:
John Bolton's new book portrays a president who is single-minded about pursuing and preserving his own interests. 

"I am hard-pressed to identify any significant Trump decision during my tenure that wasn't driven by re-election calculations," he writes. https://t.co/euXlgs0nfw

name: NPR
text:
UNC-Chapel Hill's Board of Trustees has voted to lift a 16-year moratorium on renaming campus buildings.

The board itself implemented the freeze in 2015 after agreeing to change the name of a campus building named for a reputed KKK leader.
https://t.co/OY6a5q5AqW

name: NPR
text:
"The way you saw my brother tortured and murdered on camera is the way black people are treated by police in America," Philonise Floyd told the U.N. Human Rights Council.

"You watched my brother die. That could have been me."
https://t.co/DnPpYxqBlM

name: NPR
text:
Montana is welcoming tourists back again, but the Blackfeet Nation, whose reservation borders a national park, continues to maintain a quarantine order.

One tribal member is pushing the tribe to open back up to visitors sooner rather than later. 
https://t.co/8TpL2Y864P

name: NPR
text:
President Trump told Chinese President Xi Jinping that he thought Beijing's building of prison camps for minority Uighurs was "exactly the right thing to do," John Bolton writes in his new tell-all memoir.
https://t.co/WX7TbdqFea

name: NPR
text:
Gov. Andrew Cuomo is ending the daily coronavirus briefings that millions of Americans watched over the past three months. The change reflects a steep decline in New York's infections and hospitalization rates. 
https://t.co/NBOlgsiOe3
